CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 6-1;Violation of Art. 13;Pecuniary damage - claim dismissed;Non-pecuniary damage - financial award;Costs and expenses partial award
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in PERSON , a town in LOC .
CARDINAL . Before her removal to PERSON the applicant lived and worked in GPE , a town located in Chukotka , a far - eastern territory adjacent to GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant filed with the ORG of GPE ( the “ ORG ” ) an action against her former employer , a local trading office . She wanted the defendant to pay outstanding emoluments , discharge and leave allowances , and to properly formalise her discharge .
CARDINAL . As the proceedings did not progress , in DATE the applicant complained several times about ORG to a number of higher judicial and other authorities .

CARDINAL . On DATE the President of the Judicial Qualifications Board , of GPE ( the “ ORG ” , “ Board ” ) asked the President of ORG to inform him why it took the court so long to deal with the applicant 's case and when the case would be heard .

CARDINAL . On DATE the President of the Chukotka Regional Court ( the “ ORG ” ) asked the President of ORG to start the proceedings , to fix a hearing and to inform the applicant about the date of the hearing before DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the President of ORG forwarded the applicant 's complaint to the President of ORG . He asked to inform him and the applicant about the state of the proceedings before DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the President of ORG asked the President of ORG to inform the applicant before DATE of the date when her case would be heard . He also informed the applicant that ORG could not deal with her case itself because it was understaffed . The President noted that his earlier requests to ORG had remained unanswered .
CARDINAL . On DATE the President of ORG asked the President of ORG to investigate the applicant 's complaint and take measures , if need be .

CARDINAL . On DATE the President of ORG asked the President of ORG to inform him before DATE about the state of the proceedings . He noted that the President had not responded to ORG earlier requests to speed up the proceedings . He also warned the President that he would have to apply to a judicial qualifications board if the procrastination continued .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG issued a letter rogatory by which it asked a GPE court to question the applicant . The GPE court could not execute the request because the applicant had not informed the courts that her address had changed .
CARDINAL . On DATE the President of ORG informed the applicant that her case could not be examined because ORG was understaffed and overloaded with work .

CARDINAL . On DATE the new President of ORG asked the President of ORG to forward to ORG before DATE copies of procedural documents concerning the case . She noted with displeasure that ORG had been ignoring the applicant 's earlier complaints and the ORG 's requests . She also informed the applicant that ORG had been understaffed since DATE , and that it was impossible under the law to sue the court or an individual judge for damage caused by delays in proceedings .

CARDINAL . On DATE the President of ORG asked the President of ORG to inform the ORG and the applicant before DATE about the progress of the case . She also asked the President of ORG to submit copies of procedural documents which would prove that the judge responsible for the applicant 's case had prepared the case for a hearing . She also informed the applicant that it was impossible to summon the President of ORG to the regional capital for explanations , because PERSON was located too far away from the capital and because ORG did not receive any financing for such purposes .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Deputy President of ORG noted that the President of ORG had still not informed the applicant about the progress of her case despite the earlier orders . He asked the President of ORG to provide this information to the applicant immediately .

CARDINAL . On DATE the President of ORG informed the applicant that ORG was going to visit ORG because there had been numerous complaints about its inactivity . The visit was fixed for DATE , provided that ORG would have sufficient funds for it .
CARDINAL . On DATE the President of ORG asked the President of ORG to verify the applicant 's complaints and to pass them to ORG if they proved to be well - founded .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG passed a first judgment in the applicant 's case by which her claims were granted . The defendant appealed against this judgment .
CARDINAL . On DATE the President of ORG asked the President of ORG to investigate the activity of the President of ORG before DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the President of ORG informed the applicant that ORG would investigate the activity of the President of ORG .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG granted the defendant 's appeal and remitted the case to ORG for a fresh examination .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG officially reprimanded the judge of ORG responsible for the applicant 's case for breaches of procedural rules . ORG warned the judge that she may be dismissed from service if the breaches re - occurred .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG granted the applicant 's claims in part .
CARDINAL . On DATE a public prosecutor of the Shmidtovskiy District appealed on behalf of the defendant .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG quashed the judgment and ordered a re - hearing of the case .
CARDINAL . Meanwhile , on DATE , the applicant claimed from the ORG MONEY as compensation for the delays in the proceedings . On DATE the ORG severed this claim from the main proceedings .
CARDINAL . On DATE the Shmidtovskiy Court granted the applicant 's main claims in part .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged an appeal against the judgment .
CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE ORG quashed the judgment in part and passed a new judgment by which the applicant 's claims were partly satisfied .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG closed the proceedings concerning the damage caused by the delays . The court found that there existed no law specifying how such actions should be entertained .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG quashed this decision on the ground that ORG should not have considered an action directed against itself . ORG decided that it will itself determine the court to deal with the action . These proceedings appear to be still pending .

CARDINAL . During the proceedings the applicant also made a number of complaints to ORG , ORG , the Government , the ORG and ORG . These authorities either referred her complaints to the judicial authorities of GPE or advised the applicant to do it herself .

CARDINAL . Under LAW of DATE ( “ CCivP ” ) in force at the material time , an action must be prepared for trial DATE after the action is lodged . If litigants are not located within the same town or territory , actions between them arising out of labour disputes must be examined by a court of the first instance within DATE .
CARDINAL . Under LAW CCivP , an appeal court must examine an appeal DATE after it is filed .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the Law “ On the status of judges in the GPE ” of DATE , in force at the material time , established ORG and qualifications boards of regional courts . The qualifications boards had the power to select candidates for judicial posts , to suspend or remove judges from office , to ensure judges ' inviolability and to certify judges ' professional skills . The functioning and specific powers of the qualifications boards were to be determined in special regulations .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG passed “ Regulations on Judicial Qualifications Boards ” . The ORG remained in force until DATE when a new law on the same subject was adopted . Under section CARDINAL of the Regulations , a qualifications board could :
“ CARDINAL . ... take a decision concerning the institution of criminal proceedings against a judge ... , the detention of a judge or his bringing to a court ;
CARDINAL . warn a judge to stop an activity incompatible with his position ; suspend or terminate a judges ' powers in cases [ established by law ] ;
CARDINAL . NORP examine [ complaints ] about a judge 's activity or inactivity undermining the authority of the judicial power ... ”

CARDINAL . Pursuant to section CARDINAL of the Regulations , qualifications boards could receive information , necessary for their functioning , from presidents of courts and other judges , from law - enforcement agencies and other ORG bodies , from non - governmental organisations and public officials .

CARDINAL . Pursuant to section CARDINAL of the Regulations , if an application submitted to a qualifications board was within its competence , the board had to deal with it within DATE . DATE after the board gave a decision , an extract from it had to be sent to interested parties .
